author: Dispatch
title: Outdoor museum in Holmes County opens with poetic path
text:
I love art galleries, but there’s something stirring about viewing art in the open air, especially in a beautiful setting where the serendipity of nature and the creativity of the artist can commingle and, on rare occasions, coalesce into a sublime whole.
Jason Nies, proprietor of the Inn at Honey Run in Holmes County, agrees.
Nies was visiting relatives in 2003 in Latvia, where he attended the opening of an open-air art museum and fell in love with the idea.
He bought the inn in 2009 and has been planning the Holmes County Open Air Art Museum at the site ever since.
The museum opened this month with the unveiling of the first installation, the Haiku Walk, a series of 30 haiku poems engraved on metal plaques and attached to large stones along a woodland trail near the inn.
Nies stresses that the museum won’t be just another outdoor sculpture gallery.
“We’re looking at every medium you can imagine, even performances — anything the artist can dream up,” he said.
“If you had asked me five years ago, I never would have imagined that poetry would be a part of this. And now it just happens to be our first exhibit.”
The Haiku Walk had a fortuitous origin. The Haiku Society of America, a nonprofit group that promotes the writing and appreciation of haiku, held a conference at the inn, and the organization’s regional coordinator, Julie Warther, was struck by the beauty of the site. She and Nies worked together to create the path.
Each of the ginkgo-leaf-shaped plaques contains a poem in English and Japanese. The poems were written specifically for the Haiku Walk by 26 members of the Haiku Society.
The walk reminds me of a similar installation in Hartford Conn., where each short stanza of Wallace Stevens’ poem Thirteen Ways of Looking at a Blackbird is engraved on a stone along the route the poet walked each day to the office where he worked as an insurance executive. Though not haiku, the stanzas were inspired by the form.
But the Hartford route runs through busy residential neighborhoods and noisy commercial districts — hardly the most contemplative of settings.
The verdant woodland paths of the Inn at Honey Run, however, offer a quiet canvas — one that is perfectly suited for haiku, an art form with themes that often reflect upon nature.
The poems contain three very short lines: traditionally a five-seven-five syllable pattern that is often ignored by series haiku poets. The poems usually juxtapose two diverse images joined by a linking word or phrase.
The poems on the Haiku Walk are designed to evoke the four seasons, leading visitors through nature’s yearly progression of birth, fruitfulness, death and rebirth, such as this poem by Michele Root-Bernstein near the path’s beginning:
snowmelt 
the liquid notes 
of a robin’s song 
And this by Amelia Cotter near the end:
woodland walk 
beyond our footfalls 
. . . silence 
The Haiku Walk is the first of what Nies hopes will be many pieces representing various art forms at the outdoor museum, which will be free and open to the public during daylight hours. Metal sculptor Jan Bowden, whose studio is near the inn, has been selected to install the next piece of art in early November.
